articles.headline: Supreme Court Ensures, for Now, Broad Access to Abortion Pill
articles.snippet: The order halts lower court rulings that would have restricted the drug as an appeal moves forward in a case with profound implications for abortion access and the F.D.A.’s regulatory authority.
articles.abstract: The order halts lower court rulings that would have restricted the drug as an appeal moves forward in a case with profound implications for abortion access and the F.D.A.’s regulatory authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court said Friday evening that the abortion pill mifepristone would remain widely available for now, delaying the potential for an abrupt end to a drug that is used in more than half of abortions in the United States.

articles.headline: Airman Shared Sensitive Intelligence More Widely and for Longer Than Previously Known
articles.snippet: A Discord user matching the profile of Jack Teixeira distributed intelligence to a larger chat group, days after the beginning of the Ukraine war.
articles.abstract: A Discord user matching the profile of Jack Teixeira distributed intelligence to a larger chat group, days after the beginning of the Ukraine war.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Air National Guardsman accused of leaking classified documents to a small group of gamers had been posting sensitive information months earlier than previously known and to a much larger chat group, according to online postings reviewed by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Aric Toler, Malachy Browne and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Say Hi to SoFi. It’s Suing to Force You to Repay Student Loans Faster.
articles.snippet: A self-styled “anti-bank” poached good customers from the federal loan system. When pandemic relief made that harder, it sued the government.
articles.abstract: A self-styled “anti-bank” poached good customers from the federal loan system. When pandemic relief made that harder, it sued the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The online personal finance company called SoFi first made a name for itself by rounding up money from Stanford alumni to help the university’s M.B.A. students get cheaper student loans. Later, it held mixers for single borrowers with fancy degrees. Social Finance, get it?

articles.headline: As War Rages in Sudan, Countries Angle for Advantage
articles.snippet: Even before its two leading generals went to war last week, “everyone wanted a chunk of Sudan,” an expert said of the strategically located country rich in natural resources.
articles.abstract: Even before its two leading generals went to war last week, “everyone wanted a chunk of Sudan,” an expert said of the strategically located country rich in natural resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — As war consumes Sudan, nations from around the world have mobilized swiftly.

articles.headline: Russia’s Technocrats Embraced the West, Then Enabled Putin’s War
articles.snippet: The expertise of economic officials who continue to work in the government has helped President Vladimir Putin largely keep the economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions.
articles.abstract: The expertise of economic officials who continue to work in the government has helped President Vladimir Putin largely keep the economy afloat in the face of Western sanctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after his airplane took off from Moscow last fall, a Russian energy official who had just resigned took his phone and typed up the emotions he had kept bottled inside since the invasion of Ukraine.

articles.headline: The Crypto Detectives Are Cleaning Up
articles.snippet: Early adopters thought cryptocurrencies would be free from prying eyes. But tracking the flow of funds has become a big business.
articles.abstract: Early adopters thought cryptocurrencies would be free from prying eyes. But tracking the flow of funds has become a big business.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before a new breed of cryptocurrency detectives helped bring him down, Ryan Felton marketed his crypto scheme with a grandiose promise: He was creating “Netflix on the blockchain.”

articles.headline: When Floods Destroy Homes, Hidden Costs Can Devastate Survivors
articles.snippet: While government aid and organizations can ease the burden of major losses, disaster victims are burdened by small expenses to rebuild their lives.
articles.abstract: While government aid and organizations can ease the burden of major losses, disaster victims are burdened by small expenses to rebuild their lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: When rising floodwater surrounded her home the morning of July 29, Carolyn Combs felt a sense of déjà vu. The year before, floodwater had filled the first floor of her family’s home in Jackson, Ky., damaging living spaces, storage and her two teenage children’s bedrooms.

articles.headline: Eureka! After California’s Heavy Rains, Gold Seekers Are Giddy.
articles.snippet: The mother lode of winter storms has sent water blasting through rock crevices and rivers in the Sierra Nevada, leading to more glittering discoveries by prospectors.
articles.abstract: The mother lode of winter storms has sent water blasting through rock crevices and rivers in the Sierra Nevada, leading to more glittering discoveries by prospectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLACERVILLE, Calif. — Albert Fausel spends his days at the family hardware store sorting through boxes of bolts and pacing the old, creaking floorboards to greet his loyal clientele. But on a recent sunny afternoon, he threw on his wet suit and diver’s mask and inserted himself face down in the shallow creek near his home.
articles.byline: By Thomas Fuller and Jim Wilson

articles.headline: In Abortion Pill Ruling, the Supreme Court Trades Ambition for Prudence
articles.snippet: The court’s order seemed to vindicate a commitment in last year’s decision in Dobbs: to leave further questions about abortion to the political process.
articles.abstract: The court’s order seemed to vindicate a commitment in last year’s decision in Dobbs: to leave further questions about abortion to the political process.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was an interim ruling, and the majority gave no reasons. But the Supreme Court’s order on Friday night maintaining the availability of a commonly used abortion pill nonetheless sent a powerful message from a chastened court.

articles.headline: A Chastened, Humbled Fox News? Don’t Count on It.
articles.snippet: There is little reason to think Fox News will adjust its coverage after paying a $787.5 million defamation settlement to Dominion Voting Systems. Its audience won’t let it.
articles.abstract: There is little reason to think Fox News will adjust its coverage after paying a $787.5 million defamation settlement to Dominion Voting Systems. Its audience won’t let it.
articles.lead_paragraph: After the 2020 election, the talk inside Fox News was all about “a pivot” — a reorienting of its coverage away from former President Donald J. Trump and toward the more conventional Republican politics favored by the network’s founding chairman, Rupert Murdoch.

articles.headline: At U.Va., an Alumnus Attacked Diversity Programs. Now He Is on the Board.
articles.snippet: As D.E.I. programs come under attack, a plan at the University of Virginia for “more diversity, less Confederacy” enraged some alumni, who started organizing against it.
articles.abstract: As D.E.I. programs come under attack, a plan at the University of Virginia for “more diversity, less Confederacy” enraged some alumni, who started organizing against it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bert Ellis, with two degrees from the University of Virginia, is a loyal alumnus. He has donated more than $10 million to his alma mater, and even co-owns a campus hangout, the Spot.

articles.headline: Losing Ballot Issues on Abortion, G.O.P. Now Tries to Keep Them Off the Ballot
articles.snippet: After abortion rights supporters swept six ballot measures last year, Republican legislatures seek to make it harder to get on the ballot, and harder to win if there is a vote.
articles.abstract: After abortion rights supporters swept six ballot measures last year, Republican legislatures seek to make it harder to get on the ballot, and harder to win if there is a vote.
articles.lead_paragraph: Voters pushed back decisively after the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year, approving ballot measures that established or upheld abortion rights in all six states where they appeared.
articles.byline: By Kate Zernike and Michael Wines

articles.headline: Chinese Censorship Is Quietly Rewriting the Covid-19 Story
articles.snippet: Under government pressure, Chinese scientists have retracted studies and withheld or deleted data. The censorship has stymied efforts to understand the virus.
articles.abstract: Under government pressure, Chinese scientists have retracted studies and withheld or deleted data. The censorship has stymied efforts to understand the virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in 2020, on the same day that a frightening new illness officially got the name Covid-19, a team of scientists from the United States and China released critical data showing how quickly the virus was spreading, and who was dying.
articles.byline: By Mara Hvistendahl and Benjamin Mueller

articles.headline: Bed Bath & Beyond Files for Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The company, which failed to fully reckon with the rise of online shopping, said that store closing sales would begin on Wednesday.
articles.abstract: The company, which failed to fully reckon with the rise of online shopping, said that store closing sales would begin on Wednesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bed Bath & Beyond came out of the 2008 downturn a winner. While competitors like Sharper Image and Linens ’n Things filed for bankruptcy, Bed Bath & Beyond actually expanded its business by acquiring other retailers. Its home-goods emporiums full of towels and kitchen aids — all available at a reduced price with that Big Blue coupon — were beacons that kept shoppers coming back.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: Biden Opens a New Back Door on Immigration
articles.snippet: Congress has yet to pass an immigration overhaul, but President Biden has used his executive authority to significantly expand the number of legal immigrants entering the U.S.
articles.abstract: Congress has yet to pass an immigration overhaul, but President Biden has used his executive authority to significantly expand the number of legal immigrants entering the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid a protracted stalemate in Congress over immigration, President Biden has opened a back door to allow hundreds of thousands of new immigrants into the country, significantly expanding the use of humanitarian parole programs for people escaping war and political turmoil around the world.

articles.headline: Jeff Shell, C.E.O. of NBCUniversal, Steps Down After Inquiry
articles.snippet: Comcast, the company’s owner, said he was leaving after an investigation into “an inappropriate relationship with a woman in the company.”
articles.abstract: Comcast, the company’s owner, said he was leaving after an investigation into “an inappropriate relationship with a woman in the company.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeff Shell, the chief executive of NBCUniversal, is leaving the company after an investigation into a complaint about an inappropriate workplace relationship, the company’s owner, Comcast, said in a statement on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Mullin, John Koblin and Nicole Sperling

articles.headline: U.S. Pulls Diplomats From Sudan, and an Exodus Begins
articles.snippet: With hopes fading that two warring generals will end their battle anytime soon, diplomats and other foreigners began heading for Sudan’s doors.
articles.abstract: With hopes fading that two warring generals will end their battle anytime soon, diplomats and other foreigners began heading for Sudan’s doors.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — It began with a helicopter evacuation of American diplomats from Sudan’s besieged capital city just after midnight Sunday, then turned into a full-fledged exodus of foreign officials and citizens of other nations as the battle raged around them.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh, Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: What Young Workers Miss Without the ‘Power of Proximity’
articles.snippet: One of the first major studies on remote work shows a hidden penalty of flexibility: less supervision.
articles.abstract: One of the first major studies on remote work shows a hidden penalty of flexibility: less supervision.
articles.lead_paragraph: At least 10 times a day, Erika Becker, who works as a sales development manager at a technology company called Verkada, turns to her boss with questions. “Did I handle that correctly?” she asks. “What could I have done better?”
articles.byline: By Emma Goldberg and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: China Says Chatbots Must Toe the Party Line
articles.snippet: The Communist Party outlined draft rules that would set guardrails on the rapidly growing industry of services like ChatGPT.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party outlined draft rules that would set guardrails on the rapidly growing industry of services like ChatGPT.
articles.lead_paragraph: Five months after ChatGPT set off an investment frenzy over artificial intelligence, Beijing is moving to rein in China’s chatbots, a show of the government’s resolve to keep tight regulatory control over technology that could define an era.

articles.headline: How Democrats Learned to Cast Aside Reservations and Embrace Biden 2024
articles.snippet: The president, who is expected to formally announce his re-election campaign this week, has won the full support of his party despite questions about his age and middling approval ratings.
articles.abstract: The president, who is expected to formally announce his re-election campaign this week, has won the full support of his party despite questions about his age and middling approval ratings.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For updates on President Biden’s bid for a second term, which was formally announced on Tuesday, read our live coverage.]

articles.headline: Tucker Carlson, a Source of Repeated Controversies, Is Out at Fox News
articles.snippet: Mr. Carlson has been one of the network’s top-rated hosts for many years.
articles.abstract: Mr. Carlson has been one of the network’s top-rated hosts for many years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fox News on Monday dismissed Tucker Carlson, its most popular prime-time host, who became one of the most influential voices on the American right in recent years with his blustery, inflammatory monologues on immigrants, Black civil rights activists, vaccines and national identity.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters, Katie Robertson and Michael M. Grynbaum
